An Improved Algorithm for Clustered Federated Learning

Harshvardhan, Avishek Ghosh and Arya Mazumdar
HalÄ±cÄ±oÄŸlu Data Science Institute and Department of Computer Science
UC San Diego
email: {hharshvardhan,a2ghosh,arya}@@@ucsd.edu
Abstract

In this paper, we address the dichotomy between heterogeneous models and simultaneous training in Federated Learning (FL) via a clustering framework. We define a new clustering model for FL based on the (optimal) local models of the users: two users belong to the same cluster if their local models are close; otherwise they belong to different clusters. A standard algorithm for clustered FL is proposed in Ghosh etÂ al. (2021), called IFCA, which requires suitable initialization and the knowledge of hyper-parameters like the number of clusters (which is often quite difficult to obtain in practical applications) to converge. We propose an improved algorithm, Successive Refine Federated Clustering Algorithm (SR-FCA), which removes such restrictive assumptions. SR-FCA treats each user as a singleton cluster as an initialization, and then successively refine the cluster estimation via exploiting similar users belonging to the same cluster. In any intermediate step, SR-FCA uses a robust federated learning algorithm within each cluster to exploit simultaneous training and to correct clustering errors. Furthermore, SR-FCA does not require any good initialization (warm start), both in theory and practice. We show that with proper choice of learning rate, SR-FCA incurs arbitrarily small clustering error. Additionally, we validate the performance of our algorithm on standard FL datasets in non-convex problems like neural nets, and we show the benefits of SR-FCA over baselines111The code for all experiments is available at https://github.com/harshv834/sr-fca..

1 Introduction

In modern applications like recommendation systems, natural language processing, autonomous cars, image recognition, the size of data has exploded to such a point that distributed and parallel computing has become unavoidable. Furthermore, in many applications the data is actually stored at the edgeâ€”in usersâ€™ personal devices like mobile phones and personal computers. Federated Learning, (FL) introduced in (McMahan etÂ al., 2016; KoneÄná»³ etÂ al., 2016; McMahan and Ramage, 2017) is a large scale distributed learning paradigm aimed to exploit the machine intelligence in usersâ€™ local devices. Owing to its highly decentralized nature, several statistical and computational challenges arise in FL, and in this paper, we aim to address one such challenge: heterogeneity.

The issue of heterogeneity is crucial for FL, since the data resides in usersâ€™ own devices, and naturally no two devices have identical data distribution. There has been a rich body of literature in FL to address this problem of non iid data. A line of research assumes the degree of dissimilarity across users are small, and hence focuses on learning a single global modelÂ (Zhao etÂ al., 2018; Sahu etÂ al., 2018a; Li etÂ al., 2018; Sattler etÂ al., 2019b; Mohri etÂ al., 2019; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2020). Note that learning a single model may not be sufficient in the situation where the degree of similarity is large or the users prefer to learn their personalized individual model. We direct the readers to two survey papers (and the references therein), Li etÂ al. (2020); Kairouz etÂ al. (2019) for a comprehensive list of papers on heterogeneity in FL.

As an alternative to the above, a new line of research in FL focuses on obtaining models personalized to individual users. For example Sahu etÂ al. (2018b); Li etÂ al. (2021) uses a regularization to obtaining individual models for users and the regularization ensures that the local models stay close to the global model. Another line of work poses the heterogeneous FL as a meta learning problemÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2018; Jiang etÂ al., 2019; Fallah etÂ al., 2020b, a). Here, the objective is to first obtain a single global model, and then each device run some local iterations (fine tune) the global model to obtain their local models. Furthermore Collins etÂ al. (2021) exploits shared representation across users by running an alternating minimization algorithm and personalization. Note that all these personalization algorithms, including meta learning, work only when the local models of the usersâ€™ are close to one another.

On the other spectrum, when the local models of the users may not be close to one another, Sattler etÂ al. (2019a); Mansour etÂ al. (2020); Ghosh etÂ al. (2021) propose a clustering framework, where the objective is to obtain individual models for each cluster. Note that Sattler etÂ al. (2019a) uses a centralized clustering scheme, where the center has a significant amount of compute load, which is not desirable for FL. Furthermore, it uses a top-down approach using cosine similarity metric between gradient norm as optimization objective. Also, the theoretical guarantees of Sattler etÂ al. (2019a) are limited. Further, in Duan etÂ al. (2020), a data-driven similarity metric is used extending the cosine similarity and the framework of Sattler etÂ al. (2019a). Moreover, in Mansour etÂ al. (2020), the authors propose algorithms for both clustering and personalization. However, they provide guarantees only on generalization, not iterate convergence. In Â Smith etÂ al. (2017) the job of multi-task learning is framed as clustering where a regularizer in the optimization problem defines clustering objective.

Very recently, in Ghosh etÂ al. (2021), a framework of Clustered Federated Learning is analyzed and an iterative algorithm, namely IFCA, is proposed that attains (exponential) convergence guarantees under suitable initialization. Moreover, in Ghosh etÂ al. (2021), all the users are partitioned into a fixed and known number of clusters, and the usersâ€™ in each cluster have identical data distribution. Note that, the convergence guarantee of IFCA depends crucially on suitable initialization condition (or warm start), which is also impractical for practical applications. Furthermore, it is discussed in the same paper that the knowledge about the number of clusters is quite non-trivial to obtain in applications (see (Ghosh etÂ al., 2021, Section 6.3)). Moreover, since the machines inside a cluster have data from a same distribution, the local models of all the machines in a cluster are identical (we formalize this in SectionÂ 3). This is a fairly strong assumption, since in FL applications, users who belong to same cluster, may have similar data. However, the data distribution may not be identical, and so, their local models are close, but not identical.

Following IFCA, a number of papers attempt to extend the federated clustering framework. For example, in Ruan and Joe-Wong (2021), a soft-clustering version of IFCA was proposed, where each data on a device can belong (probabilistic-ally) to different cluster. In Xie etÂ al. (2020), an IFCA inspired algorithm is proposed that uses neuron matching as distance metric. Moreover, the soft clustering idea is also discussed in Li etÂ al. (2022). To the best of our knowledge, although the above-mentioned papers extend IFCA in certain directions, the crucial shortcomings of IFCA, namely good initialization and the knowledge of the number of clusters remain unanswered.

In this paper, we propose a clustering framework for Federated Learning that overcomes the above-mentioned shortcomings. Specifically, we propose and analyze an algorithm, namely Successive Refine Federated Clustering Algorithm (SR-FCA), which iteratively estimates an refines the cluster identities of the machines. We show that, SR-FCA obtains arbitrary small clustering error. One attractive feature of SR-FCA is that it does not require the knowledge of the number of clusters apriori (instead it requires a weak condition on the minimum size of the cluster, as explained in SectionÂ 4). Moreover, SR-FCA works with arbitrary initialization, which is a major theoretical as well as practical novelty over existing literature. Furthermore, in SR-FCA we remove the requirement that all machines belonging to the same cluster possesses same local model.

To be precise, we define a novel clustering structure (see DefinitionÂ 1), based on the local models on the worker machines222Throughout the paper, we use nodes, users, machines, workers synonymously to denote the compute nodes in FL.. Classically, clustering is defined in terms of distribution from which the machines sample data. However, in a federated framework, it is common to define a heterogeneous framework such as clustering in terms of other discrepancy metric; for example in Mansour etÂ al. (2020), a metric that depends on the local loss is used.

Distance Metric: In this paper, we use a distance metric across workersâ€™ local model as a discrepancy measure and define a clustering setup based on this. Our distance metric may in general include non-trivial metric like Wasserstein distance, â„“qsubscriptâ„“ğ‘\ell_{q} norm (with qâ‰¥1)q\geq 1) that captures desired practical properties like permutation invariance and sparsity for (deep) neural-net training. For our theoretical results, we focus on strongly convex and smooth loss for which â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} norm of iterates turns out to be the natural choice. However, for non-convex neural networks on which we run most of our experiments, we use a cross-cluster loss metric. For two clients i,jğ‘–ğ‘—i,j, we define their cross-cluster loss metric as the average of the cross entropy loss of client iğ‘–i on the model of client jğ‘—j and the cross entropy loss of client jğ‘—j on the model of client iğ‘–i. If this metric is low, we can use the model of client iğ‘–i for client jğ‘—j and vice-versa, implying that the clients are similar.

With the above discrepancy metric, we put the machines in same cluster if their local models are close â€“ otherwise they are in different clusters. We emphasize that, we do not necessarily require the local models in a cluster to be identical; a closeness condition is sufficient. Moreover, the clustering identities of the workers are unknown apriori, and SR-FCA iteratively learns them. We now list our contributions.

1.1 Our Contributions

1.1.1 Algorithmic

We introduce a new clustering framework based on local user models and propose an iterative clustering algorithm, namely SR-FCA. Our algorithm starts with simple pairwise distance based clustering, and refine those estimates (and merge in necessary) over multiple rounds. We observe that the successive refinement step exploits collaboration across users in the same cluster, and reduces the clustering error. In particular, we use the first order gradient based robust FL algorithm of Yin etÂ al. (2018) for federation. We require a robust algorithm because we treat the wrongly clustered machines as outliers. However, we do not throw the outliers away like Yin etÂ al. (2018); rather we reassign them to their closest cluster.

When the loss is strongly convex and smooth, and dist(.,.)\textsf{dist}(.,.) is â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} norm, we show that, the mis-clustering error in the first stage of SR-FCA is given by ğ’ª(mdexp(âˆ’n/d)\mathcal{O}(md\exp(-n/\sqrt{d}) (TheoremÂ 1), where mğ‘šm, nğ‘›n and dğ‘‘d denote the number of worker machines, the amount of data in each machine and the dimensionality of the problem respectively. Moreover, successive stages of SR-FCA further reduce the mis-clustering error by a factor of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/m)ğ’ª1ğ‘š\mathcal{O}(1/m) (TheoremÂ 5.1), and hence yields arbitrarily small error. In practice we require a very few refinement steps (we refine at most twice in experiments, see SectionÂ 6).

Furthermore, we compare our results with IFCA both theoretically and experimentally. We notice that the requirement on the separation of clusters is quite mild for SR-FCA. We only need the separation to be Î©~â€‹(1n)~Î©1ğ‘›\tilde{\Omega}(\frac{1}{n})333Here, Î©~~Î©\tilde{\Omega} hides logarithmic dependence. On the other hand, in certain regimes, IFCA requires a separation of Î©~â€‹(1n1/5)~Î©1superscriptğ‘›15\tilde{\Omega}(\frac{1}{n^{1/5}}), which is a much stronger requirement.

As a by-product of SR-FCA, we also obtain an appropriate loss minimizer for each cluster, defined in Eq.Â (2)â€”which in conjunction with our clustering model, is a reasonable good approximation for all the machines in that cluster (see TheoremÂ 5.3). The clustering estimates are obtained by leveraging federation across similar users in a cluster. We notice that the statistical error we obtain here is ğ’ª~â€‹(1/n)~ğ’ª1ğ‘›\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{n}), which is weaker than IFCA (statistical error of IFCA is ğ’ª~â€‹(1/n)~ğ’ª1ğ‘›\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(1/n); see (Ghosh etÂ al., 2021, Theorem 2)). This weaker rate can be thought as the price of random initialization. For IFCA, a good initialization implies that only a very few machines are mis-clustered, which was crucially required to obtain the ğ’ª~â€‹(1/n)~ğ’ª1ğ‘›\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(1/n) rate. But, for SR-FCA, we do not have such guarantees to begin with, and we necessarily take a union bound on all machines, which results in a weaker statistical error.

1.1.2 Technical Novelty

A key requirement in any clustering problem is suitable initialization. However, SR-FCA removes this requirement completely, and allows the worker machines to start arbitrarily and run some number of local iterations. We show that provided the loss function is strongly convex and smooth, and the problem is well-separated, pairwise distance based clustering of these local iterates provide a reasonably good initialization, and our algorithm refines this iteratively. However, this initialization imposes further complicationsâ€”for example, an original cluster can split into multiple clusters or some machines may be unassigned to any clusters. To handle all these issues, we crucially leverage (a) sharp generalization guarantees for strongly convex losses with subexponential gradients and (b) robustness property of the trimmed mean estimator (of Yin etÂ al. (2018)).

1.1.3 Experiments

We implement SR-FCA on wide variety of datasets including synthetic, rotated or inverted MNIST, CIFAR10, FEMNIST and ShakespeareÂ Caldas etÂ al. (2018)). With â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} distance metric for synthetic and cross-cluster loss for the rest, we observe that the test performance of SR-FCA outperforms three baselinesâ€”(a) global (one model for all machines) and (b) local (one model per machine), (c)IFCA. Further, on synthetic and simulated datasets, SR-FCA recovers the correct clustering ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star}. On real datasets, SR-FCA can figure out the correct number of clusters and thus outperforms IFCA by around 4%.

2 Related Work

Data heterogeneity is a major challenge in FL, and various frameworks have been proposed in the recent past to address this. Where Zhao etÂ al. (2018); Li etÂ al. (2018); Mohri etÂ al. (2019); Karimireddy etÂ al. (2020) uses degree of dissimilarity to model the data heterogeneity, Chen etÂ al. (2018); Fallah etÂ al. (2020b, a) uses meta-learning to achieve the same.

Clustering is a canonical way to model heterogeneous data, and there is a significant interest in the community. Starting with the centralized cosine similarity based clustering of Sattler etÂ al. (2019a), and multi-task based approach of Smith etÂ al. (2017), we have the decentralized algorithm (IFCA) of Ghosh etÂ al. (2021). Furthermore, there are several variations of IFCA; for example, in Ruan and Joe-Wong (2021); Li etÂ al. (2022) soft-clustering versions of IFCA are proposed, in Xie etÂ al. (2020), the authors use neuron matching as distance metric.

Apart from this, several personalized (local tuning) models for FL use ideas from clustering. For example, Fallah etÂ al. (2020b) proposes Hypcluster algorithm, which is similar to IFCA. Moreover, Zhang etÂ al. (2021) use personalized method which uses base clustering for knowledge transfer. Furthermore, Briggs etÂ al. (2020) use hierarchical top-down clustering and then propagate local update steps down the hierarchy for better trained model.

Our final goal is to find an appropriate population loss minimizer for each cluster câˆˆ[C]ğ‘delimited-[]ğ¶c\in[C], i.e., Ï‰câˆ—subscriptsuperscriptğœ”âˆ—ğ‘\omega^{\ast}_{c}. Obtaining this involves several layers of complexity: we need to find the correct clustering ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star} and recover the minimizer of each cluster. The main difficulties in this setting are: (a) the number of clusters is not known beforehand. This prevents us from using most clustering algorithms like k-means; and (b) The clustering depends on wiâ‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–â‹†w_{i}^{\star} which we do not have access to. We can estimate wiâ‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–â‹†w_{i}^{\star} by minimizing fisubscriptğ‘“ğ‘–f_{i}, however when nğ‘›n, the minimum number of data points per node, is small, this estimate may be very far from wiâ‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–â‹†w_{i}^{\star}.

In spite of the inherent complexity of our problem, we can overcome it by utilizing federation. Note that estimating wiâ‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–â‹†w_{i}^{\star} is difficult if each node does not have enough data points. This apparent difficulty can be mitigated if instead we try to estimate Ï‰câ‹†superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘â‹†\omega_{c}^{\star}, the population minimizer for each cluster. For each cluster, we can hope that nodes in that cluster work together to improve our estimate of Ï‰ğ’â‹†superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ’â‹†\omega_{\mathcal{C}}^{\star}. But, this requires us to know the clustering. The circular nature of our problem implies that we need to use an alternating algorithm, which estimates Ï‰câ‹†superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘â‹†\omega_{c}^{\star} in one step and then tries to cluster based on the estimates of Ï‰câ‹†superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘â‹†\omega_{c}^{\star}. This forms the main idea of our clustering algorithm.

4 Algorithm-SR-FCA

In this section, we formally present out clustering algorithm, namely SR-FCA. It starts with a subroutine ONE_SHOT which outputs an initial clustering. SR-FCA then successively calls the REFINE() subroutine to improve the clustering.

In each step of REFINE(), we first estimate the cluster iterates for each cluster. Then, based on these iterates we regroup all the nodes using RECLUSTER() and then if required merge the resulting clusters, using MERGE(). We crucially require an initial clustering to start REFINE(), and ONE_SHOT provides that when REFINE() is called for the first time.

Since our goal is to end up with the correct clustering ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star} and its cluster models, it is important to understand how similar any arbitrary clustering Câ€²superscriptğ¶â€²C^{\prime} (for instance the ones generated by ONE_SHOT and REFINE) is to the original clustering ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star}. To that end, consider a cluster câˆˆrgâ€‹(Câ€²)ğ‘rgsuperscriptğ¶â€²c\in\mathrm{rg}(C^{\prime}). Then, we can first define its label with respect to ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star}.

Definition 2 (Cluster label).

We define câ€²âˆˆ[C]superscriptğ‘â€²delimited-[]ğ¶c^{\prime}\in[C], as the cluster label of cluster câˆˆrgâ€‹(Câ€²)ğ‘rgsuperscriptğ¶â€²c\in\mathrm{rg}(C^{\prime}) if the majority of nodes in cğ‘c are originally from câ€²superscriptğ‘â€²c^{\prime}.

This definition allows us to map each cluster câˆˆrgâ€‹(Câ€²)ğ‘rgsuperscriptğ¶â€²c\in\mathrm{rg}(C^{\prime}) to a cluster cğ‘c in ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star}. Using the cluster label câ€²superscriptğ‘â€²c^{\prime}, we can define the impurities in cluster cğ‘c as the nodes which did not come from câ€²superscriptğ‘â€²c^{\prime}. Therefore, if a cluster has cluster label câ€²superscriptğ‘â€²c^{\prime} and has very low fraction of impurities, it can serve as a good proxy for the original cluster câ€²superscriptğ‘â€²c^{\prime} in ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star}.

We now explain the different subroutines.

4.1 ONE_SHOT()

For our initial clustering, we create edges between nodes based on the distance between their locally trained models if ğ–½ğ—‚ğ—Œğ—â€‹(wi,wj)â‰¤Î»ğ–½ğ—‚ğ—Œğ—subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘—ğœ†\mathsf{dist}(w_{i},w_{j})\leq\lambda, for a threshold Î»ğœ†\lambda and then obtain clusters from this graph by correlation clustering of Bansal etÂ al. (2002). We only keep the clusters which have at least tğ‘¡t nodes.

If our locally trained models wisubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–w_{i}, were close to their population minimizers wiâ‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–â‹†w_{i}^{\star}, for all nodes iâˆˆ[m]ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘ši\in[m], then choosing the threshold Î»âˆˆ(Ïµ1,Ïµ2)ğœ†subscriptitalic-Ïµ1subscriptitalic-Ïµ2\lambda\in(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2}), we obtain edges between only clients which were in the same cluster in ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star}. However, if nğ‘›n, the number of local datapoints is small, then our estimates of local models wisubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–w_{i} might be very far from their corresponding wiâ‹†superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–â‹†w_{i}^{\star} and we will not be able to recover ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star}.

However, ğ’0subscriptğ’0\mathcal{C}_{0} is still a good clustering if it satisfies these requirements: (a) if every cluster in rgâ€‹(ğ’â‹†)rgsuperscriptğ’â‹†\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}^{\star}) has a good proxy (in the sense of DefinitionÂ 2) in rgâ€‹(ğ’0)rgsubscriptğ’0\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0}) , and (b) each cluster in ğ’0subscriptğ’0\mathcal{C}_{0} has at most a small fraction (<12absent12<\frac{1}{2}) of impurities in it. These requirements imply that the clusters in ğ’0subscriptğ’0\mathcal{C}_{0} are mostly â€œpureâ€ and represent all clusters in ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star}. If the loss is structured, as shown in TheoremÂ 1, we can obtain low mis-clustering error after ONE_SHOT.

4.2 REFINE():

Subroutine TrimmedMeanGD(): The main problem with ONE_SHOT(), namely, small nğ‘›n, can be mitigated if we use federation. Since, ğ’0subscriptğ’0\mathcal{C}_{0} has atleast tğ‘¡t nodes per cluster, training a single model for each cluster will utilize tâ€‹nğ‘¡ğ‘›tn datapoints, making the estimation more accurate. However, the presence of impurities in a cluster can hamper this, motivating the use of a robust training algorithm, in this case, TrimmedMean (Yin etÂ al., 2018).

This subroutine is similar to FedAvg (McMahan etÂ al., 2016), but instead of taking the average of local models, we take the coordinate-wise trimmed mean. We use Î²<12ğ›½12\beta<\frac{1}{2} to define the level of trimming and tune it in our experiments.

We end up with a trained model for each cluster as an output of this subroutine. Since these models are better estimates of their population risk minimizers, we can use them to improve ğ’0subscriptğ’0\mathcal{C}_{0}.

Subroutine RECLUSTER() The purpose of this subroutine is to reduce the impurity level of each cluster in ğ’0subscriptğ’0\mathcal{C}_{0}. This is done by assigning each client iğ‘–i to its nearest cluster cğ‘c in terms of ğ–½ğ—‚ğ—Œğ—â€‹(wc,wi)ğ–½ğ—‚ğ—Œğ—subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–\mathsf{dist}(w_{c},w_{i}). Since wcsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘w_{c} are better estimates, we hope that the each impure node will go to a cluster with its actual cluster label. If we have a cluster in rgâ€‹(ğ’â‹†)rgsuperscriptğ’â‹†\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}^{\star}) which does not have a good proxy in rgâ€‹(ğ’0)rgsubscriptğ’0\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0}), then the nodes of this cluster will always be impurities.

Subroutine MERGE(): Even after removing all impurities from each cluster, we can still end up with more than 1 cluster having the same cluster label. In ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star}, these form the same cluster, thus they should be merged. If two clusters were originally from the same cluster in ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star}, then their learned models should be very close. Therefore, we use an approach similar to ONE_SHOT, where instead of distances between client models, we take distances between cluster models, construct edges and then merge the clusters.

Note that the complete algorithm with formal descriptions of all these subroutines can be found in AppendixÂ A.

4.3 Discussion

SR-FCA uses a bottom-up approach to construct and refine clusters. The initialization in ONE_SHOT is obtained by distance-based thresholding on local models. These local models are improper estimates of their population minimizers due to small nğ‘›n, causing ğ’0â‰ ğ’â‹†subscriptğ’0superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}_{0}\neq\mathcal{C}^{\star}. However, if ğ’0subscriptğ’0\mathcal{C}_{0} is not very bad, i.e., each cluster has <12absent12<\frac{1}{2} impurity fraction and all clusters in ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star} are represented, we can refine it.

REFINE() is an alternating procedure, where we first estimate cluster centers from impure clusters. Then, we RECLUSTER() to remove the impurities in each cluster and then MERGE() the clusters which should be merged according to ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star}. Note that as these steps use cluster estimates which are more accurate, they should have smaller error

This iterative procedure should recover one cluster for each cluster in ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star}, thus obtaining the number of clusters and every cluster should be pure, so that ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star} is exactly recovered.

Note that the TrimmedMeanGD procedure also returns iterates, however, these may not have the best performance. Once we have recovered ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star}, we can run a FL algorithm inside each cluster if we need better cluster iterates.

In the next section, we will provide theoretical justification for several of our claims and establish the probability of clustering error and convergence rates for the cluster iterates obtained by TrimmedMeanGD.

5 Theoretical Guarantees

In this section, we obtain the convergence guarantees of SR-FCA. For theoretical tractability, we restrict to the setting where the dist(.,.)(.,.) is the euclidean (â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2}) norm. However, in experiments (see next section), we remove this restriction and work with other dist(.,.)(.,.) functions. Here, we show an example where â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} norm comes naturally as the dist(.,.)(.,.) function.

Proposition 1.

Suppose that there are mğ‘šm clients, each with a local model wiâ‹†âˆˆâ„dsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–â‹†superscriptâ„ğ‘‘w_{i}^{\star}\in\mathbb{R}^{d} and its datapoint (x,yi)âˆˆâ„dÃ—â„ğ‘¥subscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„(x,y_{i})\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\times\mathbb{R} is generated according to yi=âŸ¨wiâ‹†,xâŸ©+Ïµisubscriptğ‘¦ğ‘–superscriptsubscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–â‹†ğ‘¥subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–y_{i}=\left\langle w_{i}^{\star},x\right\rangle+\epsilon_{i}. If xâˆ¼ğ’©â€‹(0,Id)similar-toğ‘¥ğ’©0subscriptğ¼ğ‘‘x\sim\mathcal{N}(0,I_{d}) and Ïµiâˆ¼i.i.dğ’©â€‹(0,Ïƒ2)superscriptsimilar-toformulae-sequenceğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptitalic-Ïµğ‘–ğ’©0superscriptğœ2\epsilon_{i}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle i.i.d}}{{\sim}}\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}), then ğ”¼x[KL(p(yi|x)||p(yj|x))]=d2â€‹Ïƒ2âˆ¥wiâˆ’wjâˆ¥2\operatorname{{\mathbb{E}}}_{x}[KL(p(y_{i}|x)||p(y_{j}|x))]=\frac{d}{2\sigma^{2}}\left\lVert w_{i}-w_{j}\right\rVert^{2}.

Hence, we see that minimizing a natural distance (KL divergence) between the conditional distribution y|xconditionalğ‘¦ğ‘¥y|x for different clients is equivalent to minimizing the â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} norm of the underlying local models.

Our goal here is to recover both the clustering and clustering iterates. We first quantify the probability of not recovering the original clustering, i.e., Crâ‰ Câ‹†subscriptğ¶ğ‘Ÿsuperscriptğ¶â‹†C_{r}\neq C^{\star}. Here and subsequently, two clusters being not equal means they are not equal after relabeling (see DefinitionÂ 2).

Remark 3.

Recall that in AlgorithmÂ 1, we choose Î»ğœ†\lambda and tğ‘¡t as (any) input parameter to the algorithm. However, for the guarantees of this section to hold, we require Î»âˆˆ(Ïµ1,Ïµ2)ğœ†subscriptitalic-Ïµ1subscriptitalic-Ïµ2\lambda\in(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2}) and tâ‰¤cminğ‘¡subscriptğ‘t\leq c_{\min}, where cminsubscriptğ‘c_{\min} is the minimum size of the cluster. We emphasize that, in practice (as shown in the experiments), we treat Î»ğœ†\lambda and tğ‘¡t as hyper-parameters and obtain them by tuning. Hence, we do not require the knowledge of Ïµ1,Ïµ2subscriptitalic-Ïµ1subscriptitalic-Ïµ2\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2} and cminsubscriptğ‘c_{\min}.

Remark 4.

Although in AlgorithmÂ 1, we use correlation clustering for finding the initial clusters, in theory, we restrict ourselves to finding cliques only. Note that if there are cliques in the graph, then correlation clustering will identify them.

We start with reviewing the standard definitions of strongly convex and smooth functions f:â„dâ†¦â„:ğ‘“maps-tosuperscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f:\mathbb{R}^{d}\mapsto\mathbb{R}.

5.1 Convergence of cluster iterates:

Apart from misclustering error, we also obtain an appropriate loss minimizer for each cluster, defined in Eq.Â (2)â€”which along with our clustering model, is a reasonable good approximation for all the machines in that cluster.

Remark 11 (Convergence rate matches IFCA).

Note that the iterates converge exponentially fast to the true cluster parameter Ï‰câ‹†superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘â‹†\omega_{c}^{\star}, which matches the convergence speed of IFCA.

Remark 12 (Comparison with IFCA in statistical error).

Let us now compare the error rate with that of IFCA. Note that for IFCA, Ïµ1=0subscriptitalic-Ïµ10\epsilon_{1}=0 and the statistical error rate of IFCA is ğ’ª~â€‹(1/n)~ğ’ª1ğ‘›\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(1/n) (see (Ghosh etÂ al., 2021, Theorem 2)). Looking at TheoremÂ 5.3, we see that under similar condition (Ïµ1=0subscriptitalic-Ïµ10\epsilon_{1}=0 and hence B=0ğµ0B=0), SR-FCA obtains an error rate of ğ’ª~â€‹(1/n)~ğ’ª1ğ‘›\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(1/\sqrt{n}), which is weaker than IFCA. This can be thought of the price of initialization. In fact for IFCA, a good initialization implies that only a very few machines will be mis-clustered, which was crucially required to obtain the ğ’ª~â€‹(1/n)~ğ’ª1ğ‘›\tilde{\mathcal{O}}(1/n) rate. But, for SR-FCA, we do not have such guarantees to begin with, and we necessarily take a union bound on all machines, which results in a weaker statistical error.

Remark 13 (Potential improvement, matching statistical error of IFCA).

We use TheoremÂ 5.1 to bound probability of error for first Rğ‘…R steps and then for the (R+1)tâ€‹hsuperscriptğ‘…1ğ‘¡â„(R+1)^{th} step we use analysis from Â Yin etÂ al. (2018) to optimize for cluster iterate convergence. Note that the cluster estimates from SR-FCA are thus good approximations of Ï‰câ‹†superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘â‹†\omega_{c}^{\star}. Our iterates are obtained via TrimmedMeanGD() which assumes Î²ğ›½\beta fraction of nodes inside each cluster are corrupted. Instead, if we run any federated optimization algorithm which can accommodate low heterogeneity, for instance FedProxÂ Sahu etÂ al. (2018b), inside each cluster CRsubscriptğ¶ğ‘…C_{R}, then we can shave off the Î›Î›\Lambda term from TheoremÂ 5.3, to obtain convergence to a neighborhood of radius 2â€‹B2ğµ2B of Ï‰câ‹†superscriptsubscriptğœ”ğ‘â‹†\omega_{c}^{\star} for each cluster câˆˆCâ‹†ğ‘superscriptğ¶â‹†c\in C^{\star}.

6 Experiments

6.1 Setup

We compare the empirical performance of SR-FCA against several baselines for various datasets. Throughout the experiments, we emphasize that SR-FCA does not require the knowledge of the gap Ïµ1subscriptitalic-Ïµ1\epsilon_{1} and Ïµ2subscriptitalic-Ïµ2\epsilon_{2} or the minimum size of clusters cminsubscriptğ‘c_{\min}. Our algorithm takes Î»ğœ†\lambda and tğ‘¡t as hyperparameters, where Î»ğœ†\lambda is set by tuning and t=2ğ‘¡2t=2. The trimming level, Î²ğ›½\beta in the TrimmedMeanGD subroutine, as well as all the optimizers for each problem are also obtained by tuning. Further, we recover the clusters via correlation clustering. Since correlation clustering is NP-Hard, we use a randomized approximation algorithmÂ Bansal etÂ al. (2002) for it. Note that in all our subroutines (RECLUSTER, MERGE, ONE_SHOT), we remove any clusters which have <tabsentğ‘¡<t clients. We use â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} norm as the distance metric for Synthetic case and for other cases, we use cross-cluster loss metric.

We compare SR-FCA against 3 baselines â€“ local, global and IFCA, for 333 random seeds. The local baseline assumes that every client trains its own local model and the global baseline trains a single model via FedAvgÂ McMahan and Ramage (2017) for all machine. We report the final test performance (loss or accuracy), by averaging over the clients their test performance of each client on its model, which for local is the local model, for global is the single global model and for SR-FCA and IFCA is the cluster model for the client.

We use 3 kinds of federated datasets â€“ synthetic, simulated and real. We generate the synthetic datasets on our own, while the simulated datasets are generated from standard datasets like MNISTÂ LeCun and Cortes (2010) and CIFAR10Â Krizhevsky etÂ al. . In these two cases, the heterogeneity and actual number of clusters and cluster identity is under our control, so for these cases we also check if SR-FCA is able to recover the cluster structure. For real federated datasets, which are obtained from leafÂ Caldas etÂ al. (2018) database, we do not have this information, so we only compare final test performance.

Synthetic:

To verify our theoretical results, we first test SR-FCA for mixture of linear regression. Here, we assume two clusters, each with a different wâ‹†superscriptğ‘¤â‹†w^{\star} having dimension d=1000ğ‘‘1000d=1000. Each coordinate of wâ‹†superscriptğ‘¤â‹†w^{\star} is generated iid from a Bâ€‹eâ€‹râ€‹nâ€‹oâ€‹uâ€‹lâ€‹lâ€‹iâ€‹(0.5)ğµğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘›ğ‘œğ‘¢ğ‘™ğ‘™ğ‘–0.5Bernoulli(0.5) distribution. Each coordinate of the feature vector xğ‘¥x is sampled iid from ğ’©â€‹(0,1)ğ’©01\mathcal{N}(0,1), and we generate the target yğ‘¦y as y=âŸ¨x,wâ‹†âŸ©+Ïµğ‘¦ğ‘¥superscriptğ‘¤â‹†italic-Ïµy=\left\langle x,w^{\star}\right\rangle+\epsilon, where the noise Ïµâ€‹âˆ¼iâ€‹iâ€‹dâ€‹ğ’©â€‹(0,Ïƒ2)italic-Ïµğ‘–ğ‘–ğ‘‘similar-toğ’©0superscriptğœ2\epsilon\overset{iid}{\sim}\mathcal{N}(0,\sigma^{2}). We set Ïƒ=0.001ğœ0.001\sigma=0.001. We generate m=100ğ‘š100m=100 machines divided equally into the two clusters with n=100ğ‘›100n=100 datapoints per machine. We fit a linear model by minimizing the least squares loss for 280280280 iterations and report the final test metric. For SR-FCA, we use 111 refine step with â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} norm as the distance metric, as described in PropositionÂ 1.

Simulated Datasetsâ€“MNIST and CIFAR 10:

We generate heterogeneous federated datasets from standard ML datasets, MNIST and CIFAR10 by splitting each dataset into mğ‘šm disjoint sets of nğ‘›n data points each, one per client and inject heterogeneity via pixel inversion and rotation. For MNIST, by inverting pixel value in MNIST, we create 2 clusters (referred to as inverted in TableÂ 1) and by rotating the image by 90,180,2709018027090,180,270 degrees we get 4 clusters. For CIFAR10, we create 2 clusters by rotating the images by 180180180 degrees. Applying rotations is a common practice in continual learning setupÂ Lopez-Paz and Ranzato (2017) and also used in past FL literatureÂ Ghosh etÂ al. (2021). For MNIST and CIFAR10, we set (m=100,n=600)formulae-sequenceğ‘š100ğ‘›600(m=100,n=600) and (m=32,n=3125)formulae-sequenceğ‘š32ğ‘›3125(m=32,n=3125) respectively.

To emulate practical FL scenarios, we assume that only a fraction of the nodes participate in the learning procedure. For Rotated and Inverted MNIST, we assume that all the nodes participate, while for Rotated CIFAR10 50% of the nodes participate.

We use a 2-layer fully connected feed-forward Neural Net (NN) with 200200200 hidden units for MNIST, ResNet9Â Page (2019) for CIFAR10 and a CNN with 2 convolution and fully connected layers for FEMNIST. For MNIST and CIFAR10, we train the models from scratch while for FEMNIST, we start from a model pre-trained by FedAvg. We train Rotated MNIST, Inverted MNIST and Rotated CIFAR10 for 250, 280 and 2400 iterations respectively with 222 refine steps for SR-FCA.

Real Dataset:

We use two real federated datasets from leafÂ Caldas etÂ al. (2018) database â€“ FEMNIST and Shakespeare.

We sample m=50ğ‘š50m=50 machines from each of these datasets. FEMNIST is a federated version of EMNISTÂ Cohen etÂ al. (2017), where each client has handwritten images from a single person. Shakespeare dataset contains dialogues from Shakespeareâ€™s plays where every client has dialogues of a single character. The task for Shakespeare is next character prediction.

Since these are real federated datasets, we do not know the correct number of clusters for them, therefore, we run IFCA for 3,4,53453,4,5 clusters respectively and report the average test accuracy.

For FEMNIST, we use a CNN with 2 convolution and fully connected layers and for Shakespeare, we use a 2-layer Stacked LSTM with an embedding layer. We run FEMNIST and Shakespeare for 100010001000 and 240024002400 iterations respectively and set number of refine steps to be 222 for SR-FCA.

6.2 Results

From TableÂ 1 we can see that across all different datasets, SR-FCA outperforms all baselines.

Comparison with Local and Global Baselines:

Note that the local model has access to very little data, while the global model cannot handle the heterogeneity in different clusters. Therefore, both IFCA and SR-FCA outperform these baselines as they identify correct clusters with low heterogeneity inside each cluster. Further, the difference in test performance between these baselines and SR-FCA increases if we reduce the number of datapoints per client or increase the heterogeneity between clients.

Recovering the correct clustering ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star}:

Apart from the real datasets, the correct clustering is known to us beforehand. In these cases, SR-FCA recovers the correct clustering, if the distance metric and the threshold Î»ğœ†\lambda is tuned properly. The task of tuning Î»ğœ†\lambda is especially simplified for simulated datasets, as the heterogeneity for clients inside the cluster (i.e., Ïµ1subscriptitalic-Ïµ1\epsilon_{1}) is 0. In this setup, we observe that ONE_SHOT is near sufficient to recover ğ’â‹†superscriptğ’â‹†\mathcal{C}^{\star}. For real datasets, this observation is not true and we require multiple REFINE steps.

Comparison with IFCA:

On simulated and synthetic datasets, the number of clusters is already known, thus the performance of SR-FCA is similar to that of IFCA. However, for real datasets this is unknown, and SR-FCA clearly outperforms IFCA, especially for Shakespeare.

We first emphasize that the accuracy we report here are somewhat different compared to Ghosh etÂ al. (2021). The main reason is that for fair comparison, we average the accuracy over multiple random seed, while in Ghosh etÂ al. (2021), the maximum accuracy over seeds is reported.

As we run IFCA without initialization, we find that if clusters are empty early in training, then they remain empty throughout training. For Shakespeare, with K=5ğ¾5K=5 clusters, we ended up with 2 empty clusters. SR-FCA does not suffer from these issues due to the appropriate initialization from ONE_SHOT.

Additionally, note that the number of clusters in a small sample of a real dataset is not fixed, therefore averaged over different seeds, IFCA performs poorly for each value of Kğ¾K. SR-FCA on the other hand, can compute both the clustering and cluster iterates without the knowledge of Kğ¾K, thereby beating IFCA.

An interesting example of the issues with IFCA is the Shakespeare dataset. SR-FCA recovers exactly 111 cluster in this case, therefore itâ€™s accuracy is close to the global baseline. IFCA, on the other hand, tries to fit K=3,4,5ğ¾345K=3,4,5 clusters to this dataset and therefore performs poorly.

Key Takeaways from experiments:

We summarize the key takeaways from our experiments â€“ (1) SR-FCA outperforms all baselines across all datasets; (2) SR-FCA recovers the true clustering Câ‹†superscriptğ¶â‹†C^{\star} for synthetic and simulated datasets; (3)SR-FCA outperforms IFCA especially for real datasets.

Appendix A Algorithm Description

We provide complete descriptions for the subroutines in REFINE namely â€“ TrimmedMeanGD, RECLUSTER and MERGE.

Subroutine TrimmedMeanGD(): The full algorithm for TrimmendMeanGD is provided in AlgorithmÂ 2.

Definition 6 (TrMeanÎ²subscriptTrMeanğ›½\mathrm{TrMean}_{\beta}).

For Î²âˆˆ[0,12)ğ›½012\beta\in[0,\frac{1}{2}), and a set of vectors xjâˆˆâ„d,jâˆˆ[J]formulae-sequencesuperscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘—delimited-[]ğ½x^{j}\in\mathbb{R}^{d},j\in[J], their trimmed mean g=TrMeanÎ²â€‹({x1,x2,â€¦,xJ})ğ‘”subscriptTrMeanğ›½superscriptğ‘¥1superscriptğ‘¥2â€¦superscriptğ‘¥ğ½g=\mathrm{TrMean}_{\beta}(\{x^{1},x^{2},\ldots,x^{J}\}) is a vector gâˆˆâ„dğ‘”superscriptâ„ğ‘‘g\in\mathbb{R}^{d}, with each coordinate gk=1(1âˆ’2â€‹Î²)â€‹Jâ€‹âˆ‘xâˆˆUkxsubscriptğ‘”ğ‘˜112ğ›½ğ½subscriptğ‘¥subscriptğ‘ˆğ‘˜ğ‘¥g_{k}=\frac{1}{(1-2\beta)J}\sum_{x\in U_{k}}x, for each kâˆˆ[d]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ‘‘k\in[d], where Uksubscriptğ‘ˆğ‘˜U_{k} is a subset of {xk1,xk2,â€¦,xkJ}superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜1superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜2â€¦superscriptsubscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜ğ½\{x_{k}^{1},x_{k}^{2},\ldots,x_{k}^{J}\} obtained by removing the smallest and largest Î²ğ›½\beta fraction of its elements.

Note that TrMeanÎ²subscriptTrMeanğ›½\mathrm{TrMean}_{\beta} has been used to handle Byzantine nodes achieving optimal statistical ratesÂ Yin etÂ al. (2018). TrMeanÎ²subscriptTrMeanğ›½\mathrm{TrMean}_{\beta} can handle atmost <Î²absentğ›½<\beta fraction of the nodes being byzantine, therefore, we need ONE_SHOT to return clusters where each has <Î²absentğ›½<\beta fraction of impurities for our theoretical results.

Note that in our experiments, we use >1absent1>1 local steps and take TrMeanÎ²subscriptTrMeanğ›½\texttt{TrMean}_{\beta} when averaging local models.

Subroutine RECLUSTER(): The full algorithm is provided in AlgorithmÂ 3. Each client is sent to the cluster which is closest to it, in terms of ğ–½ğ—‚ğ—Œğ—â€‹(wi,Ï‰c)ğ–½ğ—‚ğ—Œğ—subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘–subscriptğœ”ğ‘\mathsf{dist}(w_{i},\omega_{c}).

Subroutine MERGE(): The full algorithm is provided in AlgorithmÂ 4. Similar to ONE_SHOT, we create a graph GğºG but instead with vertex set being the clusters in ğ’râ€²superscriptsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿâ€²\mathcal{C}_{r}^{\prime}. Then, we add edges between clusters based on the threshold and find all the clusters in the resultant graph GğºG by correlation clustering. Then, each of these clusters in GğºG correspond to a set of clusters in ğ’râ€²superscriptsubscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿâ€²\mathcal{C}_{r}^{\prime}, so we merge them into a single cluster to obtain the final clustering ğ’r+1subscriptğ’ğ‘Ÿ1\mathcal{C}_{r+1}.

Appendix B Proof of PropositionÂ 1

According to the proposition, for two users iğ‘–i and jğ‘—j, the data is generated by first sampling each coordinate of xâˆˆâ„dğ‘¥superscriptâ„ğ‘‘x\in\mathbb{R}^{d} from ğ’©â€‹(0,1)ğ’©01\mathcal{N}(0,1) iid and then computing yğ‘¦y as â€“

D.3 Proof of LemmaÂ 4

Prâ¡[âˆƒcâˆˆrgâ€‹(ğ’â‹†)â€‹Â such that no cluster inÂ ğ’0Â has cluster labelÂ c]â‰¤âˆ‘câˆˆğ’â‹†Prâ¡[No cluster inÂ â€‹ğ’0â€‹Â has cluster labelÂ c]Prğ‘rgsuperscriptğ’â‹†Â such that no cluster inÂ ğ’0Â has cluster labelÂ csubscriptğ‘superscriptğ’â‹†PrNo cluster inÂ subscriptğ’0Â has cluster labelÂ c\displaystyle\Pr[\exists c\in\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}^{\star})\text{ such that no cluster in $\mathcal{C}_{0}$ has cluster label $c$}]\leq\sum_{c\in\mathcal{C}^{\star}}\Pr[\text{No cluster in }\mathcal{C}_{0}\text{ has cluster label $c$}] (20)

Here, we use union bound over the clusters for the second inequality. Now, we analyze the probability that no cluster in rgâ€‹(ğ’0)rgsubscriptğ’0\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0}) has cluster label cğ‘c for some câˆˆrgâ€‹(ğ’â‹†)ğ‘rgsuperscriptğ’â‹†c\in\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}^{\star}). Since the size of each cluster in rgâ€‹(ğ’0)rgsubscriptğ’0\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0}) is atleast tğ‘¡t and there are Cğ¶C clusters in rgâ€‹(ğ’â‹†)rgsuperscriptğ’â‹†\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}^{\star}), if all clusters in rgâ€‹(ğ’0)rgsubscriptğ’0\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0}) have â‰¤tCabsentğ‘¡ğ¶\leq\frac{t}{C} nodes from cluster cğ‘c, then no cluster will have cluster label cğ‘c.

â‰¤\displaystyle\leq Prâ¡[âˆ‘âˆ‘ğ’â‹†â€‹(i)=ğ’â‹†â€‹(j)=câ€‹Xiâ€‹j>Scâ€‹(Scâˆ’tC)]Prsuperscriptğ’â‹†ğ‘–superscriptğ’â‹†ğ‘—ğ‘subscriptğ‘‹ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptğ‘†ğ‘subscriptğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ¶\displaystyle\Pr[\underset{\mathcal{C}^{\star}(i)=\mathcal{C}^{\star}(j)=c}{\sum\sum}X_{ij}>S_{c}(S_{c}-\frac{t}{C})]

â‰¤\displaystyle\leq expâ¡(âˆ’a1â€‹cmin)subscriptğ‘1subscriptğ‘\displaystyle\exp(-a_{1}c_{\min})

In the first step, we require each node iğ‘–i to have Scâˆ’tCsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ¶S_{c}-\frac{t}{C} wrong edges. For the second inequality, we remove the intersection and thus, the total number of incorrect edges has to be Scâ€‹(Scâˆ’tC)subscriptğ‘†ğ‘subscriptğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ¶S_{c}(S_{c}-\frac{t}{C}), since each node has Scâˆ’tCsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘¡ğ¶S_{c}-\frac{t}{C} incorrect edges. A necessary condition for us is 1âˆ’tCâ€‹Scâˆ’pm>01ğ‘¡ğ¶subscriptğ‘†ğ‘ğ‘ğ‘š01-\frac{t}{CS_{c}}-\frac{p}{m}>0 which translates to t<Câ€‹Scâ€‹(1âˆ’pm)ğ‘¡ğ¶subscriptğ‘†ğ‘1ğ‘ğ‘št<CS_{c}(1-\frac{p}{m}). We use the lower bound a1subscriptğ‘1a_{1} and Scâ‰¥cminsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘subscriptğ‘S_{c}\geq c_{\min} to obtain the final inequality. Plugging this in EqÂ (20), we obtain our result.

D.4 Proof of LemmaÂ 5

Pr[âˆƒcâˆˆrg(ğ’0)Â which hasÂ â‰¥Î±Â fraction of impurities]â‰¤âˆ‘câˆˆrgâ€‹(ğ’0)Pr[clusterÂ cÂ hasÂ â‰¥Î±Â fraction of wrong nodes]\displaystyle\Pr[\exists c\in\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0})\text{ which has $\geq\alpha$ fraction of impurities}]\quad\leq\sum_{c\in\mathrm{rg}(\mathcal{C}_{0})}\Pr[\text{cluster $c$ has $\geq\alpha$ fraction of wrong nodes}] (21)

We use a simple union bound on clusters in ğ’0subscriptğ’0\mathcal{C}_{0} for the above inequality. D.8 Proof of LemmaÂ 3

The remainder of the proof follows that of LemmaÂ 8.

Lemma 11.

If f,g:â„dâ†’â„:ğ‘“ğ‘”â†’superscriptâ„ğ‘‘â„f,g:\mathbb{R}^{d}\to\mathbb{R} are two Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex functions on a domain ğ’²ğ’²\mathcal{W}. Then, f+g2ğ‘“ğ‘”2\frac{f+g}{2} is also Î¼ğœ‡\mu-strongly convex on the same domain.

Lemma 12.
